article.title: Significantly high polarization degree of the very low-albedo asteroid (152679) 1998 KU$_\mathrm 2$

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main point illustrated by Figure 1?
choices: The linear polarization degree of 1998 KU2 decreases at larger phase angles.
1998 KU2 shows a similar polarization degree trend as other low-albedo objects across observed phase angles.
1998 KU2 exhibits a significantly higher linear polarization degree than other low-albedo objects at comparable phase angles.
The linear polarization degree of 1998 KU2 is independent of the observed wavelength.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the dashed line in Figure 2 represent?
choices: The predicted polarization phase curve for Ch- and Cgh-type asteroids.
The observed polarization phase curve for other C-type asteroids with low albedo.
The predicted polarization phase curve for F-type asteroids.
The average polarization phase curve for high-polarization comets.

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion can be drawn from the consistency of the PSF profiles in Figure 3?
choices: 1998 KU2 exhibits strong cometary activity in both optical and mid-infrared observations.
The presence of a significant dust coma surrounding 1998 KU2 is evident.
1998 KU2 does not display any detectable source extension or cometary activity in the observed data.
1998 KU2 exhibits a distinct tail-like feature indicative of cometary activity.

multiple_choice_question.text: Based on Figure 5, what can be inferred about the surface regolith structure of 1998 KU2?
choices: The surface likely consists of compact carbon particles with sizes greater than 20 Î¼m.
The observed polarization degree of 1998 KU2 can be solely explained by the presence of Orgueil-like materials.
The high polarization degree suggests the presence of micron-sized fluffy aggregates composed of nano-sized carbon grains on the surface.
The surface is likely covered in a thick layer of Allende-like materials based on the observed polarization degree.
